raw_text:
Roddick into San Jose final
 
 Andy Roddick will play Cyril Saulnier in the final of the SAP Open in San Jose on Sunday.
 
 The American top seed and defending champion overcame Germany's Tommy Haas, the third seed, 7-6 (7-3) 6-3. And Saulnier survived an injury scare in his semi-final with seventh-seeded Austrian Jurgen Melzer. The Frenchman twisted his ankle early in the second set but overcame Melzer, who was left fuming over a series of line calls, 6-7 (3-7) 6-3 6-3. "I was feeling horrible earlier in the week," Roddick said. "I thought tonight was another step in the right direction. "On my returns, I was standing in more and I'm getting a little more depth, even if I don't hit a perfect return."
 
 Roddick won the last four points of the first-set tie-break before being broken at the start of the second set. But he broke straight back and then broke Haas again to lead 4-2. "It's extremely frustrating when you have chances against a top-five player and don't do anything with them," admitted Haas. "I rushed a few backhands and he took advantage." Saulnier will move into the world's top 50 for the first time after his passage through to the final. "It's taken a lot of work and a lot of fighting in my mind," he revealed. "Sometimes I didn't believe I could get to a final and now I am here. I've stayed mentally strong. "I'm on the way. I'll keep fighting and work a lot and I'll be up there."
llama3.2:1b: Andy Roddick played Cyril Saulnier in the SAP Open final in San Jose, defeating Tommy Haas 7-6 (7-3) 6-3 after Haas suffered an injury scare in his semi-final match.
Roddick broke Haas twice to lead 4-2 in the second set, but was broken again at the start of it.
He then broke Saulnier to take the first set tie-break and win the final 7-5.
llama3.2:3b: Andy Roddick defeated Tommy Haas 7-6 (7-3) 6-3 in the SAP Open final, while Cyril Saulnier overcame an injury scare to beat Jurgen Melzer 6-7 (3-7) 6-3 6-3.
gemma2:2b: Andy Roddick defeated Tommy Haas in the semi-finals of the SAP Open in San Jose to advance to the final, where he will face Cyril Saulnier.
Saulnier overcame an injury scare and won his semi-final against Jurgen Melzer.
Roddick's return game improved, leading him to victory after a tie-breaker in the first set.
Saulnier will enter the top 50 of the ATP rankings for the first time.
qwen2.5:0.5b: In the SAP Open event in San Jose, Andy Roddick played against Cyril Saulnier.
Roddick won set 6-4 with 7-6 (7-3) while Saulnier played in a semi-final.
Both players were injured early in the match.
Roddick's return was better than his first serve, and he broke Haas again to lead 5-2.
He then lost set 4 in a tie-break.
Saulnier was stronger and won in the second round.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Andy Roddick advances to the SAP Open quarterfinals against Cyril Saulnier, who overcame injury in his semi-final victory over Jurgen Melzer.
Roddick beats top-seeded Haas 7-6 (3) 6-3 before Saulnier wins a match-ending comeback over fourth seed Melzer, moving into the world's top 50 with a win at the San Jose tournament.
qwen2.5:3b: Andy Roddick will play Cyril Saulnier in the final of the SAP Open in San Jose on Sunday.
Roddick, an American top seed and defending champion, defeated Tommy Haas, third seed from Germany, 7-6 (7-3) 6-3.
Saulnier, after overcoming Jurgen Melzer in a tough semi-final with an ankle injury scare, will play his first final due to advancing.
Roddick credited better returns for his success against Haas.
Saulnier expressed determination and mental strength as he prepares for the final.

The American top seed and defending champion overcame Germany's Tommy Haas in a 7-6 match.
He survived an injury scare in the semi-final with Austrian player Jurgen Melzer who was left fuming over a series of line calls.
The Frenchman played Saulnier at the SAP Open, which he won last four points of before being broken at the start of the second set.
He has also managed to lead 4-2 after his arrival and defeat Haas in the final.

The American top seed and defending champion overcame Germany's Tommy Haas, the third seed, 7-6 (7-3) 6-3.
And Saulnier survived an injury scare in his semi-final with seventh-seeded Austrian Jurgen Melzer.
The Frenchman twisted his ankle early in the second set but overcame Melzer, who was left fuming over a series of line calls, 6-7 (3-7) 6-3.
"I was feeling horrible earlier in the week," Roddick said.
"I thought tonight was another step in the right direction."
On his returns, he was standing in more and was getting a little more depth, even if he doesn't hit a perfect return.
"It's extremely frustrating when you have chances against a top-five player and don't do anything with them," admitted Haas.
"I rushed a few backhands and he took advantage."
Saulnier will move into the world's top 50 for the first time after his passage through to the final.
"It's taken a lot of work and a lot of fighting in my mind," said Saulnier.

Saulnier will keep fighting and he'll be up there eventually.
He'll stay focused on his game and he'll work hard to overcome any obstacles that come his way.
